titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William A. Speck Papers
titlestmt.author: by Christa Sammons

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 05:36

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Collection consists of correspondence, notes and drafts, card files, personal and family papers, documenting the founding of the Speck Collection and William A. Speck's activity as a Goethe collector and interpreter.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The William A. Speck Papers consist of material brought to Yale by Speck and generated by him while he was curator of the Speck Collection. The papers were left in the library when Speck died, except for a small section of personal papers purchased from a descendant in 1960.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William A. Speck Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William A. Speck Papers. Yale Collection of German Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The correspondence series was preliminarily processed by Christa Sammons in the 1970s or 1980s. The rest of the collection was preliminary processed and described by Christa Sammons in 2007.

bioghist.head: WILLIAM A. SPECK (1864-1928)
bioghist.p: William Alfred Speck, the founder of the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana, was born in New York City to German immigrants, Otto Speck, a pharmacist, and Natalie Adolphine Haase. He was married twice, to Lillie Day Robinson in 1893 (she died three years later) and to Sara Rennie Speck, the widow of his brother Oscar. His professional training was at the Pharmaceutical College in New York City, and from 1883 until 1912 he worked in the family drug store in Haverstraw, New York. All the while, he was amassing a major Goethe library, and in 1913 he accepted Yale's invitation to come to the university and deposit his collection in the library. He acted as its curator from 1913 until his death in 1928 and as lecturer in the Yale Graduate School beginning in 1916.

A more detailed biography of Speck may be found in the National Cyclopedia of American Biography (vol. 29) and in Goethe's Works with the Exception of Faust: A Catalogue . Edited by Carl F.Schreiber (New Haven, 1940), p. 21-42. Schreiber's account of Speck's early years is based on a text written by Sara R. Speck and preserved among the Speck Collection manuscripts (YCGL MSS 6, folder 657).

bioghist.head: History of the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana
bioghist.p: Yale acquired the Speck Collection in 1913 through a set of fortuitous coincidences. Speck's niece, Charlotte Keeney, belonged to the Vassar College Class of 1912. Perhaps at her uncle's suggestion, she took several Goethe courses in college, at least one of them taught by Marian Parker Whitney, a daughter of Yale's distinguished Sanskrit scholar William Dwight Whitney. In February 1912, Charlotte Keeney arranged for Ms. Whitney and a group of Vassar students to visit Uncle Will's Goethe collection, already numbering some 6,000 items, at his home in Haverstraw, New York. Recognizing the importance of the collection and perhaps encouraged by her father (who had studied in Germany and taught German at Yale), Marian Whitney suggested to the Yale University Librarian John Christopher Schwab (Class of 1886 and grandson of the German writer Gustav Schwab) that he might visit the remarkable collection on the Hudson. The German literary scholar Julius Petersen, visiting professor at Yale during the year 1912/13, also saw the collection and arranged for part of it to be exhibited at the University. Hanns Oertel, another native German and dean of the Yale Graduate School, lent his support to the project, as did Alfred Lawrence Ripley, Yale Class of 1878, who had taught German at Yale before becoming a banker and Fellow of the Yale Corporation. Within a year, Yale had negotiated the acquisition of the Speck Collection, bringing William Speck to New Haven as its first curator. These events are documented in the correspondence files of Marian Whitney, John Christopher Schwab, Julius Peterson, Hanns Oertel, Anson Phelps Stokes, and the material filed under Yale University, Office of the Secretary, which includes the drafts of the original contract between Speck and Yale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William A. Speck Papers document the founding of the Speck Collection and Speck's activities as a Goethe collector and interpreter, both before he came to Yale and during his tenure as curator at the University Library. The collections consists of card files, personal and family papers, correspondence, and notes and drafts for articles and lectures.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collections is organized into four series: I. Card Files, circa 1914-1927. II. Personal and Family Papers, 1848-1951. III. Correspondence, circa 1893-1928. IV. Notes and Drafts for Articles and Lectures, circa 1870-1927.

did.unittitle: Card file of the Ehrhardt Faust Collection, arranged by the collector's numbering system, mostly in an elegant German hand, probably the collector's. (paper slips approximately 4x6 inches)

Cards listing William A. Speck's activities relating to the collection year by year, including publications issued, courses taught, and lectures given. In some cases, student attendance records are present.
Cards headed "special funds," which appear to record individual monetary gifts and what was purchased with each.
Card file of donors in kind, listing the donated items.
Paper list of the collection in William A. Speck's hand recording 2,021 items. Incomplete?
Card file of Speck Collection. This file appears to supplement rather than duplicate the one in Box 3. The cards for manuscripts are in William A. Speck's hand. (3x5 index cards)
Botanical specimens collected by William A. Speck around Haverstraw, NY

scopecontent.p: Includes medical bills, a certificate of introduction from the State Department (1897), a testimonial from the College of Pharmacy, City of New York (1883), and a certificate concerning Otto Speck's apprenticeship at a pharmacy in Germany (1848)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These family papers were found in an envelope marked as follows in the hand of Hedwig S. Dejon, then librarian of the German Literature Collection: "This material concerning Mr. Speck and his family (including some photographs) was sold to YUL [Yale University Library] for a nominal sum by one of the descendants (unidentified) now living in Tennessee. Received 2/23/60 from Accessions Division."

did.unittitle: Photographs. Included are persons and houses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File includes letters from his nephew William, 1907 March 16; two letters to his sister Augusta, 1897 and n.y; two letters to Sara R. Speck, 1928 and n.y.

did.unittitle: Sara R. Speck, correspondence from Yale librarians Schreiber and Keogh
Sara R. Speck, family letters: from and about her son Oscar O. Speck and his wife Eleanor H. Speck; "Bill," possibly her son William; and "Annie," possibly William's second wife

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a mixture of business, academic, and institutional correspondence, with a few letters from old friends who have nothing to do with Yale or Goethe but often relate to Speck's other interests, such as botany and geology. The correspondence sometimes gives brief glimpses into his politics, especially the letters from Oswald Garrison Villard.

Orders, invoices, offers, and letters from antiquarian dealers in Germany, England, France, the United States, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and Japan document the growth of the Speck Collection from its inception in the late 1880s until Speck's death in 1928. The earliest evidence of his collecting is in the file for E. Steiger & Co. in New York City, with whom William Speck placed a subscription to the Weimar Edition of Goethe's works in 1887. Many of the earliest invoices in the collection are for coins and medals, suggesting that portraits and likenesses of Goethe were among Speck's earliest collecting interests. The most extensive dealer files are Maggs Brothers in London, Joseph Baer in Berlin, and Leo Liepmannsohn in Leipzig. These files, along with many shorter files of correspondence with other dealers, bridge the private and Yale years of Speck's collecting activity.

The correspondence also documents acquisitions from private individuals, such as the extensive negotiations to acquire a group of Goethe-related autographs from the Chicago collector Oliver R. Barrett in exchange for U.S. Presidential letters. A similarly wide-ranging correspondence preceded the purchase of the manuscript of Bayard Taylor's Faust translation. Private collections were also purchased in Germany during Speck's Yale years, among them the 6,000 pieces of Faustiana gathered by G. W. Ehrhardt (acquired in 1922) and 4,000 prints, maps, and ephemera amassed by Karl Berg and purchased from his widow Anna in 1928. The Ehrhardt purchase is an example of the way many Germans were forced to sell their collections because of the severe inflation in Germany after the First World War. Speck's correspondence files of the 1920s are, in fact, full of letters from private individuals offering Goethe-related possessions, in the hope of obtaining small amounts of hard cash in dollars. While Speck took advantage of this situation to augment the collection, it is also clear that he rescued numerous people in extremely difficult circumstances.

In developing the Goethe collection at Yale, Speck had solid support from several faculty members and officers of the University. Among the notable correspondence files in this regard are the letters from Professor Gustav Gruener of the German Department; from Carl F. Schreiber, who was to succeed Speck as curator of the collection; from Anson Phelps Stokes, Secretary of the University; from Hanns Oertel, Dean of the Graduate School; from John Christopher Schwab, University Librarian; and from William Lyon Phelps, perhaps Yale's most illustrious professor of English at the time. Phelps often wrote in German, and once signed himself "Wilhelm Löwe Phelps."

Special mention should be made of the extensive file of letters from Alice Pearl Raphael, whose translation of Goethe's Faust I was published in New York by J. Cape and H. Smith in 1930. Alice Raphael adopted Speck as her principal advisor as she worked on the translation, often traveling to New Haven for consultations. After Speck's death, she continued to write to Sara R. Speck and to Carl F. Schreiber. Related letters are to be found in the Wilson Follett file. Alice Raphael's papers are part of the Yale Collection of German Literature. (In the Speck correspondence, Alice Raphael's letters are filed under her married name, Eckstein.)

Speck's interest in English translations of Goethe has, in fact, given enduring shape to the Speck Collection, with its particular strength in the reception of Goethe's works in Great Britain and the United States. His research on the English novelist, traveler, and linguist George Henry Borrow, for instance, threads through both the correspondence and the essay series of the papers and led to an exchange of letters with the notorious forger Thomas Wise, who made a gift to the collection of several Borrow manuscripts. George Borrow translated Ferdinand Maximilian Klinger's 1791 novel Fausts Leben, Thaten und Höllenfahrt , and manuscripts of Borrow's English renderings of scenes from Goethe's Faust are present in the Speck Collection (YCGL MSS 6, folders 225-27).

did.unittitle: Notes and drafts for articles and lectures

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by title or subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The files in this series range from short bibliographic jottings and transcriptions such as scholars necessarily made before the advent of the copy machine, to fully formed lectures. They are all handwritten by Speck, usually in pencil on half sheets of yellow paper.

William A. Speck had no graduate degree in German literature and published little in the field, aside from the series Facsimiles and Reproductions of Unique or Rare Items from the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana (Yale University Press, six numbers, 1915-27) and an article on the Faust translator George Borrow. Yet both his correspondence and material in the notes and drafts series of his papers show that Speck was an active teacher and popular speaker. He addressed several Modern Language Association meetings, spoke at colleges and schools in Connecticut, Massachusetts, and New York State, and gave lectures before the Yale Germanics Club, church and women's groups, and the Yale library staff. The lectures and notes also include several series of talks: twenty-one essays on the portraits of Goethe; a packet of twenty-three lectures on Goethe's personality; twelve lectures on Faust, from the sources of the legend to the completion of Goethe's Faust II, and two on Faust in art; and six biographical lectures on Goethe. These series represent Speck's presentations in the two courses he offered at the Yale Graduate School, "Goethe's Personal Appearance" (1916/17 and 1919/20) and "Goethe and His Personal Influence," given first in 1917/18 and in several subsequent years. The biographical lectures on Goethe appear to have been presented almost annually in one of Gustav Gruener's courses beginning in the fall of 1919.
